awd_titl_txt: Teacher-training to transform classrooms, teachers and communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program and supported by SBE's Economics program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Abhijit Banerjee at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist studying the ways in which a novel pedagogical approach can influence teacher ability and effort and student learning outcomes. Ensuring quality teaching is a challenge around the world, so it is natural to ask: how can teacher quality and effort be improved? Attempts to answer this question by using material incentives (e.g., increased salaries or increased pay for performance outcomes) have not produced definitive answers. The fellow and sponsoring scientist have partnered with an NGO that implements a novel teacher training to gain insights into the multifaceted challenge of increasing teacher motivation and ability. The teacher training instils in teachers a love of learning by deepening their appreciation and understanding of the scientific method. By gaining the ability to practice methods of scientific inquiry, teachers begin to see both themselves and their students as scientists with the responsibility of building on accumulated knowledge to provide benefits to local communities. They thus become researchers with a social mission to apply and generate learned and, respectively, new knowledge to improve student and community outcomes. A core hypothesis of the study is that teachers' love of learning is transferred to students through a new orientation towards knowledge and its potential uses.

The proposed research employs a randomized control trial design to establish causal linkages between the teacher training and relevant outcomes. Fifty schools out of 100 are randomly selected to send teachers to participate in the teacher training. The study will compare outcomes in treatment and control schools to test hypotheses using originally collected datasets that include information on teacher attitudes, student learning and community outcomes. The study will be among the first to advance understanding about sources of intrinsic motivations in teachers and how they can be tapped to create qualitative and quantitative improvements to teacher quality and student learning. This is a significant contribution - studies examining links between teacher effort and monetary incentives often lead to outcomes that do not correlate with student learning. Additionally, the study will explore whether the pedagogical approach from the training leads teachers, and subsequently students, to apply knowledge to influence local community processes. Such an experience may lead to more creative economic activity, deeper engagement in civic processes. Thus, a second contribution of the study is that it demonstrates the ways in which different pedagogical approaches generate local and immediate returns to education in addition to delayed returns stemming from human capital investments the leads to workforce participation later in life. A second goal of the fellowship is to examine how nation-wide teacher training and recruitment strategies can tap into such sources of motivation to influence teacher quality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The last few decades have witnessed a large rise in school enrollment in developing countries with no equivalent rise in student learning. This is largely attributed to poor quality of teaching, characterized by "chalk and talk" pedagogy and an emphasis on rote learning in classrooms. Despite this, there is surprisingly little evidence about approaches to improve general teaching skills and teacher quality.

This NSF project made strides to fill this gap, resulting in a paper titled "Learning to Teach by Learning to Learn" co-authored by Vesall Nourani, Nava Ashraf and Abhijit Banerjee (2020). The authors study a teacher training in Uganda with quite dramatic impacts. They followed over 30 upper primary (middle) schools over a two-year period, working with a partnering organization to offer a teacher training to roughly half of the schools at random. In the schools that benefited from the teacher training (in which only 40% of teachers were trained after two years), 50% more students passed a high stakes exam allowing them to continue into secondary school.

A cohort of teachers participates in the training over the course of a year. Each cohort attends three sessions during school holidays over the course of the academic year. In the first part of the training, teachers learn to think and learn to learn like scientists. In other words, they learn how to observe and describe their village and the world around them with increasing clarity, how to pose sharp questions, and infer answers from data and evidence from their own immediate community. The second part of the training invites them to engage in a meta-cognitive analysis of this learning environment. In other words, they ask themselves "what were the pedagogical features of this learning environment that promoted a new way of learning and experience with knowledge?" This stage of the training was often accompanied by a recognition that their own approaches to teaching limited student learning to a single dimension -- that of information assimilation (or memorization) -- instead of various other forms of learning that include critical thinking, exploration of one's environment, conceptual learning and more.

To reiterate, the training helps teachers value a diverse pedagogical toolkit through the experience of diverse ways learning. The metacognitive analysis of this toolkit helps teachers learn to appreciate how different pedagogies affect different dimensions of these learning outcomes. As the teacher learns to match pedagogy with an equally diverse set of learning objectives and this process describes what it means to learn how to teach.

The effects observed on standardized test scores are all in the 90th percentile (or above) of changes in learning outcomes in global studies of education interventions studied using similar methodologies. Additionally, the authors develop new measures of student learning to provide further evidence that suggests teachers are adapting pedagogy to diverse modalities of learning. One such measure includes the use of science shows as a means to measure students' scientific competencies. In the science shows, students are tasked with demonstrating ways of preserving soil and treating water in their communities for safe drinking. Students in treated schools demonstrated far more competency in the use of scientific methods and principles to address these challenges than students whose teachers did not participate in the training.

This class of "learning to learn" teacher trainings are very different from the more dominant approach to teacher training that sets very specific teaching goals and lays out the exact steps to get there. It does this while also being among the most cost-effective programs seen to date.

While the research described above was a central feature of this project, throughout the project the Fellow engaged in conversations with key policy makers in Uganda. He presented results on at least 4 occasions within Uganda and over 20 occasions in total in academic and other spaces around the world. These presentations have made it possible to expand the reach of the teacher training program to secondary schools. The Fellow is now working together with partner organizations to consider how to take the approach to scale through government teacher professional development systems and beyond.

While the research described above can be considered the central element of the funded project, the Fellow also helped develop novel educational experiences for Ugandan graduate students at Makerere University. During the Covid-19 induced lockdowns, the Fellow also managed to develop village research networks to learn how increased capacity for the use of scientific methods in village settings can affect development trajectories. The Fellow is able to build on these projects in the next chapter of his academic career.
